div1.p: Carter provides specific details about the financial arrangement regarding Brown's assistance on the manuscript for the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 10, 1928
div1.opener:

Washington, D. C.
May 10, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of May 5th. asking further details
relative to my tentative arrangement with Miss Brown:

As I wrote you on April 28th. Miss Brown told me, when we
had our first talk on the subject of her helping me with the biblio-
graphy of the History of Yellow Fever, that would she ask me approximately
the same rate of compensation per hour that she was receiving for her [unclear] work
at the Library of Congress. Her salary is $200.00 per month.

Miss Brown's actual working hours at the Library are 6 1/2
hours per day--i. e. from 9 A. M. to 4.30 P. M. with an hour off for
lunch, during which hour she works with me. (Says she never takes
any lunch.)

1: Miss Brown however, is only asking me $65.00# to $75.00 a month for the
106 hours work. This, according to whichever amount seems fair to me (really to you) She has
also offered to give me more time, if I need it, without any increase in
compensation, after the end of May, when she finishes up some other special
work. Naturally, this is far below the rate she first mentioned to me, even
if one included the lunch hours, which I have deducted.
This, because she has become very much interested in the work and is, I think,
really enjoying our joint efforts therein. Miss Brown's services are well
worth $75.00 a month, but I am sure that she will be satisfied at anything
decided on within the radius mentioned. Naturally, as per your previous in-
structions, Miss. Brown considers the arrangement made with me, personally

2: (a) As to how Miss Brown should be paid: she has left that matter en-
tirely to me, but I should think, if the salary asked meets with your appro-
bation, that it would be better to put it on a monthly basis, as Miss Brown
is giving me at least 24 hours a week of intensive work, and, if she were
paid weekly, it would seem proper to keep closer to the approximate pay per
hour than she is asking by the month--i. e. to pay her somewhat over, $94.00 a month versus
the $65.00 or $75.00 already mentioned.

(b): As to actual payment of Miss Brown's salary: I can either pay
her myself and send you, or the Comp the cancelled check as a voucher for reimbursement
-2-
reimbursement,
or you can advise the Comptroller to send me the additional money for Miss
Brown's salary when he sends my check, in which case I can also send you
my cancelled check to Miss Brown, since you wish her salary to be paid her
through me and not directly from the Foundation. Of course, if our work
together terminated before the end of a month, I should only pay her for
the amount of work done. Equally, if she were ill, or had to stop for some
other reason.

Frankly, if you approve the continuation of Miss Brown's services,
I shall consider that we will be indeed fortunate to secure so unusually
well equipped a person at so moderate a compensation. This especially after
what I had been told on the subject by Dr. Putnam and others at the Library,
as well as what I had heard from outside sources.

With very best wishes, and assuring you that Miss Brown and I
are both working as hard as ever we can.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
P. S. I might have made this letter shorter, and equally clear, if
I had taken more time to it, but such time would have had to be taken from
the bibliography--hence I'm sure you will pardon its length. For the same
reason (to save time) I've given approximate statistics for the hours of work Miss
Brown does for gives us vs. the Library of Congress: counting theirs the balance
(at the salary she asks us, & the hours she gives us) is really more in our
favor than I have made it, as she frequently has several times given us an extra 3 hrs. on
the nights when she is not supposed to work for us, according to our
present agreement.
L.A.C.
